t: Job 14
Job Continues: Death Comes Soon to All
“Man*pn who is born of a woman is*ld few of days and full of trouble.
He*ln comes out like a flower and withers; he*ld flees like a shadow and continues not.
And*ln do you open your eyes on such a one and*ld bring me into judgment with you?
Who*ln can bring a clean thing out of an unclean? There*ld is not one.
Since*ln his days are determined, and*ld the number of his months is with you, and*ld you have appointed his limits that he cannot pass,
look*ln away from him and leave him alone, that*ld he may enjoy, like a hired hand, his day.
“For*pn there is hope for a tree, if*ld it be cut down, that it will sprout again, and*ld that its shoots will not cease.
Though*ln its root grow old in the earth, and*ld its stump die in the soil,
yet*ln at the scent of water it will bud and*ld put out branches like a young plant.
But*ln a man dies and is laid low; man*ld breathes his last, and where is he?
As*ln waters fail from a lake and*ld a river wastes away and dries up,
so*ln a man lies down and rises not again; till*ld the heavens are no more he will not awake or*ld be roused out of his sleep.
Oh*ln that you would hide me in Sheol, that*ld you would conceal me until your wrath be past, that*ld you would appoint me a set time, and remember me!
If*ln a man dies, shall he live again? All*ld the days of my service I would wait, till*ld my renewal should come.
You*ln would call, and I would answer you; you*ld would long for the work of your hands.
For*ln then you would number my steps; you*ld would not keep watch over my sin;
my*ln transgression would be sealed up in a bag, and*ld you would cover over my iniquity.
“But*pn the mountain falls and crumbles away, and*ld the rock is removed from its place;
the*ln waters wear away the stones; the*ld torrents wash away the soil of the earth; so*ld you destroy the hope of man.
You*ln prevail forever against him, and he passes; you*ld change his countenance, and send him away.
His*ln sons come to honor, and he does not know it; they*ld are brought low, and he perceives it not.
He*ln feels only the pain of his own body, and*ld he mourns only for himself.”
